venue.name: Signal Ridge Trailhead (2 miles down Sawyer River Rd off Rte 302)

item.description:
This is a great hike with A+views for the effort.

Sunday's early forecast is favorable:  Overcast with a chance of rain in the afternoon. High of 64F. Winds from the SE at 5 to 10 mph. Chance of rain 20%.

Description: The old logging town of Livermore, incorporated in 1876 and named for Samuel Livermore, was once a thriving settlement whose population dwindled by the end of WWII when the forests had been denuded.

Just 6 miles west of Bartlett, the school house, post office, and many remnants of dwellings and foundations remain on the bank of the Sawyer River Road not far from the parking lot.

This hike goes through a splendid hardwood forest with many types of beautiful flora everywhere.

After most of the elevation gain is completed to reach Signal Ridge, hikers are rewarded by the sudden spectacular views for a delightful mile of easy ridge walking.

We'll have a short descent into the woods and a short ascent up to the (4680') bald summit with sensational views of 43 4000 footers in NH and scores of mountains in Maine & Vermont.

The stunning views from the open summit and tower are contenders for the finest views in all the Whites!

The round trip is normally 10.0 miles, 3250' of elevation gain, with 8 - 8.5 hours on the trail.

CARRIGAIN BROOK IS A WIDE WATER CROSSING. IF WE GET A LOT OF RAIN THIS COULD BE DIFFICULT TO CROSS. TREKKING POLES ARE ADVISED.

Reaching the summit is a bonus, and we will turn around if conditions are not favorable and safe for the group.
